The attached voucher #313, dated May 15th, 1948, in the amount of $35.24 made payable to the B.C. Power Commission, Alert Bay, covers electricity used in the New Alert Bay Indian Day School and Teacherage.

For the Department's information, when the new school was under construction the Surveys and Engineering Branch had the building hooked up to use electricity. The teacherage was also on the same line. At that time the Company were unable to supply a meter and this was not installed until the beginning of the year. The amount of electricity consumed before the meter was installed was estimated.

As part of the electricity should rightly be charged to the construction of the new school, we have been endeavouring to get the matter straightened out but without success; so we are submitting the account as is and would recommend that it be paid.

APPLICATION FOR TUITION GRANT

1. Name of Applicant: Charles Garfield WILSON
2. Age: 21, Sex: Male, Band and number: No. 24-A Cape Mudge
3. Name of School attended by Applicant: Alberni Indian Junior Residential School
4. Number of years at school: 9, Grade attained: 9
5. Name of school which applicant wishes to attend: Alert Bay Superior White School
6. Course which applicant wishes to follow: Junior Matriculation and possible further education in order to enable him to obtain a position in the Civil Service of Canada, Indian Affairs Branch.
7. Usual length of course: 3 years
8. Yearly cost of course: $260.96; Next two years approximately the same as 1946-47.
9. Yearly amount that will be paid by Applicant's parents or Guardian: Approx. $200.00
10. Each amount deducted from Indian Affairs Branch: $96

CANADA
Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

RE: K-1998, Pte. WILSON, Charles Garfield, Cape Mudge Band.

On October 16th last I was interviewed by Charles Garfield Wilson, ex-soldier, at Courtenay, who had been discharged from the Service under date of Feb. 27th, 1946, after having served in the United Kingdom and Continental Europe. This was the first time I had met Wilson since he returned from Overseas.

He informed me upon receiving his discharge he made application to the D.V.A. to re-enter high school and take advantage of his educational grant allowed by the D.V.A. to Veterans who had served Overseas. Wilson informed me that after months of effort on his part to obtain the grant he was informed by the D.V.A. that he could not pass the tests and, therefore, he was not eligible and nothing could be done for him; the reasons being as follows:

(1) It seems the D.V.A. grant is primarily for a University education and only nine months high school course is permitted, which is merely a refresher period preparing them for University.

(2) No provision is made for a high school education other than the above, evidently thinking that all Service men would have completed their high school education prior to the time of enlistment.

In the case of Charles Wilson he attended Alberni Residential School and took his Grade 9 there before being discharged. As his Grade 9 in this school gave him no standing insofar as the Provincial Department of Education is concerned, it was not recognized by the D.V.A. In addition to taking Grade 9, Charles, by his own initiative and expense, went to night school in Vancouver and took three months in Grade 10, while he was working in the Boeing Aircraft, Vancouver, during the beginning of the war; but he found that working and going to night school was too hard and had to give up his studies. He remained employed in the Boeing Aircraft, Vancouver, on war work until he volunteered for Service and enlisted on the 24th day of January, 1944.

Wilson has ambition to be educated and to obtain a position in the Civil Service of Canada in the Indian Affairs Branch - that is why he did everything possible to continue his studies through the D.V.A.

After Wilson informed me of his disappointment in not being able to receive any benefits from the D.V.A. insofar as helping him with an education, he asked if there was anything the Indian Department could do to assist him.

p.t.o.
This was already the middle of October and I realized that if any action was to be taken it had to be done at once, otherwise he would lose a complete year. I also felt the Department would not want any deserving Indian Veteran to be deprived of an education on account of regulations which did not apply in his particular case, through no fault of his own. As he was so discouraged and yet so anxious to continue with his studies, I suggested that he come to Alert Bay where I would make every effort to help him.

Upon my return home I interviewed Principal Wickens to see if it was possible for Charles Wilson to be put on the school staff as part-time employee where he could live in the school and take a Correspondence Course. Mr. Wickens was short-staffed at the time and I was under the impression that it would be of assistance to him and at the same time help this lad. Mr. Wickens declined. I then referred the matter to the Principal of the Alert Bay Superior White School, the Provincial School Inspector and the School Board for the area, all of whom were immediately sympathetic to my problem and agreed to accept him as a correspondence student in the school, with the understanding that the Principal was to assist him in his studies. The Provincial Department of Education has also been very co-operative.

This letter is somewhat lengthy but I have been faced with an unusual situation and wish to give the Department all the facts in respect to same, and felt the Department would expect me to do everything possible to assist this Indian Veteran. It has taken considerable time to overcome all the difficulties experienced because the education he received at the Reserve School could not be recognized by the Provincial Authorities and the D.V.A. I am pleased to tell the Department arrangements were made for him to take up his studies on October 31st last, and he has made good progress ever since. The Principal of the White School has assisted him in reviewing Grade 9 work and he is now taking Grade 10 and should complete it at the end of the term.

In making these arrangements it was necessary to find a boarding place for him as well as purchase his books and pay for his registration fee with the Department of Education. A statement and voucher covering room and board and books is attached herewith with my recommendation. Possibly I should state Mrs. Daniel Hanuse of Alert Bay agreed to provide him board and room and do his washing for $30.00 a month. This is very reasonable in comparison to other charges made for the same service. Total cost to the Department to June 30th, 1947, will amount to $260.95.

It is our intention that he immediately start Grade 11 July 1st, 1947, continuing his Correspondence Course. We hope to have this completed by December 31st, 1947. He will also take Grade 12 by Correspondence Course and have it completed by December, 1948. I am not sure as yet what it will cost the Department for Grades 11 and 12 - it will all depend on what arrangements I can make for him, but in any case it would not be more than the amount asked for, for this year.

I am attaching hereto a brief report from Mr. S. J. Heywood, Principal of Alert Bay Superior White School, which will speak for itself. Mr. Heywood has just told me that Charles is doing exceptionally well, that he has seen his marks and is very pleased with the progress he is making. Application for Tuition Grant is also enclosed.

Encs.

I am forwarding herewith an application for tuition grant for Charles Garfield Wilson of the Cape Mudge Band and a letter in support of this application from Mr. Indian Agent Todd.

MEMORANDUM

Re: K.19985 - WILSON, C. G.

With reference to letter from Indian Agent Todd, dated 31 December, 1946, on file hereunder, the Veterans Affairs Department does not provide assistance for education such as that required by Wilson.

If a veteran has matriculated before leaving the services, grants can be made to assist him in a university course. Should it be necessary, he will be granted a refresher course of one term for the purpose of ensuring that he is capable of keeping pace with his first year. If he lacks one year of completing matriculation, a grant can be made to him for this purpose and continued in the university course. Where a veteran has not the above standards he may receive assistance in vocational or technical training, but there is no provision for assisting a veteran to complete two or three years of high school.
Ottawa, 15 January 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 7th instant regarding an application for tuition grant for Charles Garfield Wilson. It is noted that Mr. Wilson is a member of the Cape Mudge Band and a returned soldier who is not eligible for education advantages allowed to veterans who served overseas.

In view of the information contained in your letter and also Indian Agent Todd's communication, we will allow Wilson a tuition grant of $260.96 which it is understood will be sufficient for the period ended June 30, 1947. In your letter you mentioned $460.96 but it is evident from Agent Todd's letter that this was a typographical mistake.

Arrangements will be made to pay the two vouchers which you submitted.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. MacKay:

Re Lillian Matilpi

This letter will confirm our telephone conversation of recent date with regard to the above mentioned girl.

Our staff have been so pleased at Lilly's progress since she came to the Institute for training, that we feel she should be given added opportunity. The Canadian National Institute for the Blind train a certain number of their most promising blind girls as Home Teachers, who go out into the homes of the blind people to teach them Braille and handicrafts.

However, before a girl can enter training, she must be at least 20 years of age and have some high school, preferably matriculation. We have discussed Lilly with Mr. C.E. McDonald of the School for the Deaf and Blind, who has agreed that, your Department willing, Lilly should enter the School and take high school work with the understanding that she then be given training under the Canadian National Institute for the Blind as a Home Teacher at the end of 2 or 3 years. Lilly is herself most anxious to take advantage of this opportunity.

There will not be accommodation available at the School until the end of February, but the lady with whom Lilly is staying, has agreed to act as her guide to and from the School until that time.

We would appreciate receiving your approval of this plan and any comments you care to make.

Yours sincerely,

"Eileen Scott"
Social Welfare Dept.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Mrs. Pogson, teacher of the Port Essington School, having resigned, the future of the few children at this village has been given consideration. There is a white school in the village. Most of the pupils attending same are of mixed Indian-White stock and are nearly all related to the youngsters attending the Indian school.

I have discussed this matter at length with Inspector E. E. Hyndman and he is prepared to recommend that our Indian school children be admitted to the white school at Port Essington and make it a combined school. He informs me that there may not be enough pupils to keep his school open with whites alone. From our point of view, it is going to be practically impossible to secure a teacher to live in the conditions prevalent at Port Essington. The total cost of a teacher, fuel and all supplies should be in excess of what we would pay to the Area School Board for taking these children in. The white school is as close to the homes of our children as is the Indian Day School. If the deal is put through, the School Board would like to have the use of the oil heater now installed in our School.

The move is strongly recommended. Average attendance during the year at our school has been 11.06. Will you advise if I may proceed to secure a per capita figure for tuition from the School Board and submit same for consideration of the Department.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: District Inspector of Indian Schools.

I refer to copies of letters of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield concerning the admission of Indian pupils to the Port Essington Elementary School.

It is noted that the cost of tuition for these pupils is higher than the Department has been paying in the past, but it does not cover the total cost. The situation at this point is somewhat different, inasmuch as the Indian pupils will apparently make up about half of the school population. The operation of a combined school at Port Essington would represent a saving for the School Board and for the Department over the operation of separate schools.

It is recommended that the offer of the Prince Rupert School Board be accepted, and that Mr. Anfield be requested to submit applications for tuition grants for the pupils who will be enrolled at this school.

I am enclosing a letter dated November 18th from Mr. Indian Agent Todd received here today, together with Application for Tuition Grant for Reginald Wilson, twenty year old Indian of the Cape Mudge Band, who is presently attending the University of British Columbia. This boy is a brother of Charles Garfield Wilson for whom the Department approved a tuition grant, reference Mr. Neary's letter of September 10th (file 103-156), and apparently it was the original intention that the boy's parents meet the cost of his education.

Reginald Wilson was interviewed in this office recently and stated that his parents were not in a position to meet these costs and that fees for the first half of the university term, and other expenses, had been paid by himself from his earnings during the summer but that he would be unable to meet any further costs.

Under the circumstances and providing his academic standing at the University after Christmas warrants continuation of his studies I would recommend that the Department approve a grant of $211.50 in this case. I may say that if his academic standing after Christmas is not satisfactory he will not be permitted to remain at the University in any case. I would therefore suggest that an accountable advance of $211.50 be forwarded to Mr. Letcher, Acting Indian Agent, Alert Bay.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

RE: CRAMER, Gloria - Student Greater Victoria High School, Victoria, B.C.

Gloria has completed her Grade 11, University Entrance Course, at Victoria High School, and wishes to continue her studies. Her ambition is to be a doctor. Gloria has received a satisfactory report from the principal and will be entering Grade 12 when she returns to high school on September 7th.

As I am anxious to help this student I am recommending that the Department again assist her to the extent of $450.00.

Gloria is a very capable girl, has been working in the Indian Office here during the holidays and I have had an opportunity to really judge her worth, and I believe she has what it takes to succeed if given financial assistance. Gloria is the oldest girl in a family of eight. She has worked during summer holidays to help pay for her transportation to and from school and also to help pay for her clothes, etc. Her father is helping her as far as he can. Her parents are most anxious that she continue with her studies.

As Gloria will be returning to school at the beginning of September, it would be appreciated if an early reply could be received. In this case it is not necessary to send an accountable cheque as we will be receiving accounts covering board, etc., and will be submitting them direct to Ottawa for payment.

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Superintendent.

He will be taking third year subjects but will be registered as a second year student because of the necessity of completing the French course which he failed last term.

Mr. Scow has requested a continuance of the assistance given him by the Department last year but has asked that the amount be increased from $445.00 to $520.00. This amount is broken down as follows:

Fees - $205.00
Board - $315.00

Mr. Scow will be making a contribution of approximately $250.00. The requested increase is due to an increase in the cost of board.

It is recommended that the department approve a grant of $320.00 to cover the cost of board and tuition up to the end of December at which time we will obtain a statement from the University as to the results of this student's examinations. This statement will be forwarded to the Department as soon as it is received with a recommendation. It is requested that if the Department approves this suggestion an accountable advance for $200.00 be forwarded to this office.

October 27th, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa

Tuition Grant - Reginald Wilson
Cape Mudge Band
Your file 103-156 (WT 1)

The question of a tuition grant for the above named to enable him to attend University was the subject of correspondence with you last year, reference Mr. Neary's letter of September 20th. Apparently in response to my letter of January 5th an accountable advance of $211.50 was forwarded to the Acting Indian Agent at Alert Bay to cover expenses during the second half of the school term but in the interval due to illness of his father Reginald was absent from University for a period of one month and fell so far behind he did not consider it advisable to continue that year.

He is again registered at the University this year, however, and has paid $115 in fees and slightly over $20.00 for books. He is able to finance room and board for a period of two months but beyond that requires Departmental assistance. I have discussed this matter with Supt. Todd who agrees that a grant of $200 toward payment of fees for the latter half of the academic year and for some assistance with books, etc., would be warranted. I have interviewed Reginald and feel that he will do his best this year. I would recommend that in this case a grant of $200 be approved.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
November 3, 1948.

Mr. W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 27th ultimo regarding Reginald Wilson. We have also reviewed Indian Commissioner MacKay's letters of December 9th, 1947 and January 5th, 1948.

We feel that Superintendent Todd should have requested you to advise the Department when Reginald Wilson was returning to University. If you refer to letter of January 5th, 1948, you will note that we were informed that he withdrew from the University at that time because in the opinion of the University authorities, continuation of his studies was not warranted.

Could you obtain a report from the University authorities indicating whether or not an additional expenditure in the case of this boy would be warranted.

As you realize, we have numerous requests from all parts of the country for tuition grants and as far as possible we must be assured that when we authorize such grants, the pupil has a reasonable chance of success.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Application for Tuition Grant

Attached are completed form for Melvin and Donald Assu of the Cape Mudge Band. These students were previously attending the Heriot Bay High School on Quadra Island which is close to their home and anticipated returning to this school at the beginning of the present academic year. However when they sought admission they were refused by the school board on the ground that there was insufficient accommodation for their own pupils and they could not accept Indian children. On learning this the father of the boys made arrangements for them to attend the King Edward High School in Vancouver. The father is paying the complete cost of board and lodging and is requesting only that the Department pay the tuition fees and cost of books.

It will be understood that it was impossible for the Superintendent to anticipate this request.

It is recommended that a grant of $136.00 be approved for each of these pupils.

These students were interviewed in the Vancouver office by Inspector Davey who has completed the application forms and signed for the Superintendent who concurs in the recommendation.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Mr. A.C. Lipp,
Secretary, Board of School Trustees,
District No. 72,
Campbell River, B.C.

Dear Mr. Lipp:

In view of the construction plans of the Board of School Trustees No. 72 for the erection of a new school on Quadra Island and the intention of the Indian Affairs Branch to build a new two room school at Cape Mudge it would appear that there is an opportunity for co-operation in the construction of a school which would serve either all or part of the Indian pupils as well as the white community. This suggestion is made because it is felt that the present segregation of Indians is retarding the development of our Native people and that the admission of Indian children to white schools is one of the most effective ways of overcoming this segregation. In addition to this factor, the increased enrolment which would result would make possible a larger school and improved facilities. As your Board is probably aware, School Boards in other parts of the Province have agreed to cooperate in plans of this nature.

Although the situation may not be exactly parallel an outline of the procedure which was followed and the basis upon which an agreement was reached in one instance may be of interest to your Board. At Hazelton where the Indian Reserve is adjacent to the white community, both the school Board and the Indian Affairs Branch required new schools. The School Board was approached by the Indian Affairs Branch with a proposal that the public school be constructed sufficiently large to accommodate the Indian pupilage. The Indian Affairs Branch agreed to pay to the Department of Education the proportion of the capital cost which the Indian pupilage bore to the total enrolment. The Indian Affairs Branch also agreed to pay tuition fees for each pupil for whom it is responsible at the rate of the net per capita cost to the school board.
It was agreed that the control of the school was to remain entirely in the hands of the Board. The School Board gave assurance that there would be no segregation of Indian children in separate class-rooms. These proposals were agreed to in principle by the School Board but felt that it was largely a local matter and that acceptance should be subject to the agreement of the majority of the rate payers resident in that section of the district affected. A meeting of this group accepted the proposal and the preliminary planning for the new building is now being undertaken.

If your Board is prepared to consider a similar plan I shall be pleased to submit after further study a definite proposal.

Yours sincerely,

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.

If your Department will share the proportion of Capital cost, which the Indian pupilage bore to the total enrolment and the net per capita cost for tuition fees, it is the intention of the Board of School Trustees, District No. 72 to include the enrolment of Indian children at Campbell River and Quadra Island as soon as new buildings are constructed.

The enrolment of Indian children in any other part of District No. 72 would be decided on application by your Department.

Your letter of January 20th, 1949 covers many points not necessary to include in this letter, i.e. control to remain in the hands of the Board, children's health report, subject to the approval of ratepayers resident on Quadra Island and Campbell River, no segregation of Indian children in separate class-rooms, etc.

28th April, 1949.

Mr. M.S. Todd,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Alert Bay, B.C.

We are in receipt of your Voucher No. 234 amounting to $831.30 covering the cost of tuition of Indian children who attended the Comox Elementary School during the quarter ended March 31st, 1949. During that quarter this school charged $16.30 per month for each pupil. At the end of December, 1948, we were only paying at the rate of $3.50 a month.

The heavy increase in the monthly rate, which it is presumed will continue in the future, emphasizes the fact that we will be obliged to exercise more strict supervision regarding those for whom we will be able to allow a tuition grant.

Consequently, before August 1st, 1949, you should forward us a list of those pupils for whom you consider a tuition grant should be allowed at the school mentioned above. In the case of those who have already attended, you should let us have a report from the Principal of the school, indicating that they were successful during the academic year 1948-49 and have been promoted to a higher form for the academic year 1949-50.

In the case of new pupils whom it is considered should enter the Comox Elementary School for the first time during the academic year 1949-50, a separate form should be forwarded.
for each pupil. A supply of these forms is enclosed.

The information requested should, of course, be sent through the office of Indian Commissioner Arneil, to whom a copy of this letter is being forwarded.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education

Dear Sir:

I refer to your letter of February 11th concerning the possible admission of Indian children from the reserves at Campbell River and Cape Mudge to schools in District No. 72. This matter has been referred to the head office of the Indian Affairs Branch with a request for permission to proceed with negotiations. I have been requested to secure further information as to the approximate number of pupils involved, the type of school to be built at Campbell River and Quathiaski Cove and the approximate cost of each building. I shall appreciate your supplying me with this information if possible.

With regard to the probable enrolment, will you please include figures for the white population only. I have checked the number of Indian children, both of school age and pre-school age and have attached a copy of a summary of this. The grade placement indicated is for the current year.

At both Cape Mudge and Campbell River I feel that the Primary Grades (1 to 3) should continue to attend our own schools.

I have requested the Indian Affairs Branch to authorize my proceeding with negotiations with your Board for the
admission of the Indian pupils from the Cape Mudge and Campbell River Reserves with standings of Grade 4 and above to the two schools at Quathiaski Cove and Campbell River on the same basis as the agreement reached at Hazelton as outlined in my previous letter of January 20th. At Cape Mudge this would involve the admission of approximately 25 (including the 8 pupils now attending Grades 7 and 8 at the Heriot Bay School) and 16 at Campbell River including the pupil already enrolled in Grade II.

Should your board wish to discuss this matter with me I shall be pleased to attend a meeting at the convenience of the members.

Yours sincerely,

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

Owing to the shortage of labour and the difficulty I have found in getting the Janitor work done at the Skidegate Indian Day school, I would like to recommend that the janitor's salary be raised from the present $6.00 per month to $10.00 per month.

The duties of the janitor is to chop the wood (for two class rooms) lights both fires every morning, sweep out the school every day, and scrub the rooms out as often as required, and do odd jobs or minor repairs as requested by the teacher in charge.

If the above recommendation is approved, I would like to suggest that the $10.00 per month commence for the month of May, 1944.

B.T. Phillips,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Phillips' letter of the 21st ultimo requesting authority to increase the janitor's allowance at Skidegate Indian Day School from $6.00 to $10.00 per month as under present labour conditions it is impossible to get the work done for the amount now provided.

This school is a fairly large two-room school where heating is necessary for a considerable period during the winter owing to the dampness of the climate and I consider the present allowance inadequate. I would, therefore, recommend approval of the request that it be increased to $10.00 per month.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.

I have to refer to your letter, dated Oct. 18/45, in connection with education of Indian children at the Provincial School at Cespeeco, and to report having visited that point and investigated the matter.

The present Day School is situated on the Cannery site at Cespeeco; but it is about to be moved to Doctor McLean's property at Esperanza...a matter of 2 miles.

A survey of the children available for the school shows only two who could attend with any pretence to regularity, as the population of the Cannery is composed of Indian families employed during the Fishing season. Only the children of such families not in school during the season are mostly from Ahousat, and they attend school at Ahousat from November to June.

I spoke to the teacher and inspected the school, and also interviewed the trustees, and am satisfied that the school is being conducted according to the regulation of the Provincial Board of Education.

The children attending regularly are Robert Adams, age 9; and Samuel Adams, age 12; orphans, and have both attended since September 1, 1945.

I would respectfully recommend that attendance be authorized for these children, also for any other children whose parents may be in a position to send them regularly during the school term.

I have requested the school trustees and the teacher to submit names of prospective pupils in order that the applications may be properly investigated.

P. B. Ashbridge
Indian Agent
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The Provincial Government has recently created a school district near Ceepeecce known as the Hecate-Tahsis school district and a day school has been in operation on the Cannery site, Ceepeecce, for some time, but will likely be moved to Esperanza, a matter of two miles, in the near future.

Two Indian children, Robert Adams, age 9, and Samuel Adams, age 12, have been attending this school since September 1st and Mr. Ashbridge's letter of December 3rd recommending that the Department pay the usual tuition grant for these children is enclosed herewith. It will be noted that there likely are other Indian children who should be attending this school, but pending receipt of a further report from the Indian Agent in this connection I would recommend that the Department authorize the usual grant of $5.00 per annum, based on attendance, for each of these children.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 27th ultimo, addressed to this Department at Ottawa, has been referred to me for attention.

It is noted that you state that Indian children of elementary school age are being forced to do without an education due to lack of accommodation and that there are approximately forty beginners on the Reserves in the Valley who will not be able to start school. I would advise that this problem was discussed with the Indian Agent at Alberni last year with a view to the construction of a new school on the Opetchesahlt Reserve at Alberni, but unfortunately lack of building material has prevented any development of our plan but I understand that most of the children on this Reserve are attending the Residential School at Alberni.

As I have no definite information, I am asking the Acting Indian Agent at Alberni for a report showing exactly how many children are not attending school and suggesting that he interview you with a view to securing their admission to the white schools in the neighborhood contingent upon our Department paying the school fees. We circularized all our Indian Agents asking that any Indian children who are not attending school be ensured of immediate attendance where white schools would arrange to take them, without waiting for specific authorization by this office, submitting the details later.

Your interest in the matter is greatly appreciated and it is sincerely hoped that your discussion with Mr. Garrard, the Acting Indian Agent, will result in some alleviation of the condition complained of if it exists.

Dear Miss Wood:

Re: Marjory Joseph - 17 yrs
Clayoquot Band

The a/n is the daughter of Mrs. Edward Joseph, widow of the Clayoquot Band and has expressed a desire to attend High School with a view to obtaining Junior Matriculation and then going into training for a nursing career.

Due to the fact that the school term is two months old this office took the liberty of having this girl take an aptitude test with Mr. Caldwell and Mr. Dunn, the Principal of the Alberni District High School, and the results were very favourable. Mr. Dunn agreed to take Marjory as a Grade 9 pupil and she is now attending as such. It is hoped the Department will approve of our actions in this case.

The Fee for the Academic year is $50.00, rental of Books $3.50.

Mr. Caldwell has no space in the girls dormitory for Marjory regardless of which it was not considered advisable to place a Catholic in a Protestant School even as a boarder. Marjory was formerly a pupil at the Christie Residential School.

Pearl Clutesi, an aunt, of the Sheshahlt Band has offered to take Marjory for room and board at a minimum of $35.00 per month ($280.00 for the remainder of the year) as of November 1, 1949. As Pearl is already supporting a family of her own this is considered to be reasonable. She keeps herself and her home very clean and tidy and is considered to be very reliable.
It would be greatly appreciated if authority could be granted for Marjory to attend the Alberni District High School at the charges above mentioned and that an amount of $35.00 per month be authorized in favour of Pearl Clutesi for Marjorie's room and board while attending High School.

As you know this Agency is sadly lacking in pupils seeking to advance their education in view of which your favourable consideration of this request would be appreciated.

Re: Application for tuition grants
for Indian Children attending White
Schools

In the enclosed estimates I have listed the approximate number of
children which may be attending the various white schools in this agency.
Some of these schools I have on previous occasions endeavoured to have
the Indian children enroll, and this year I will be making additional
efforts and hope to be more successful. Following are listed the
approximate number of children which I hope will be attending white
schools:

ALBERNI GILL SCHOOL: This school has not yet been constructed but
it is hoped by September 1951, that the pupils now attending the
Indian Day School may be admitted to this school and it is expected
that the tuition fees will be in the neighbourhood of $5.00 per month.
The number of pupils expected to attend will be approximately 50,
making a total for the half year September 1950-April 1951-$1750.00.$1750.00

ALBERNI DISTRICT HIGH SCHOOL: It is anticipated 10 pupils will attend
this school in the 1950-51 year. The rate of this school will
possibly be $75.00 per pupil per year making the total $750.00.

BAMFIELD ERIC GODSON MEMORIAL SCHOOL: 6 pupils have been attending
this school and it is anticipated that a similar number will be
on the roll during 1950-51 year. This school has not sent in an
account for their children but I believe if this is done it will be
at the rate of $5.00 per month for the 10 school months, totalling
$300.00.

ESPERANZO PUBLIC SCHOOL: The attendance of this school varies greatly,
when the cannery is operating a number of Indian Children from Ahoosat
go to Esperanza with their parents increasing the number in
attendance but the average for this school will be approximately 6
pupils and it is anticipated that accounts for their tuition will
be submitted, the rate again here being $5.00 per month totalling
$300.00; in addition at this school a mid-day meal is supplied at
35¢ per meal totalling $399.00. Transportation is also supplied
here at the rate of $1.00 per day, irrespective of how many are
transported, this would amount to $190.00.

PORT RENFREW: There are 10 pupils of school age residing within 1
mile of the white school at Port Renfrew. I have on two previous
occasions unsuccessfully endeavoured to have these pupils admitted
to this school, further efforts will be made this year and it is hoped
with better success. Fees for this school, it is anticipated will
be $5.00 per month a total of $500.00.

N. W. Garrard,
Superintendent
Indian Agency.

ASSISTANCE TO EX-PUPILS
Sir;-

I beg to inform you that the Reverend Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School has recommended the following pupils, discharged at the conclusion of the summer holidays, for rewards for good conduct and diligent study.

Pupil No.171 Charley Thomas Johnson is recommended for a set of carpenter's tools. This boy has shown a marked aptitude for woodworking, has been diligent and well-behaved and will, I am satisfied make very good use of such a reward.

Pupils Nos.0-171 Anastasia Wycott
0-168 Agnes Sandy and
0-165 Mary Margaret John are recommended for sewing machines. I have always found that ex-pupils who receive sewing machines continue to carry on the work taught them in the School, to great advantage, in making economical clothing for themselves and their families. The machines are always properly cared for and constitute their most prized possessions.

Will you kindly inform me if these recommendations are approved and also if the Department issues any diplomas to such departing pupils.

Your obedient servant,

H.E.Taylor
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Dept.of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, September 15, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, regarding the request of the Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School that a set of carpenter tools be supplied for ex-pupil No. 171, Charley Thomas Johnson, and a sewing machine to each of ex-pupils Nos. 0171, Anastasia Wycott, 0165, Agnes Sandy and 0165, Mary Margaret John.

Regarding the supplying of sewing machines to ex-pupils, I have to say that these are usually only supplied to girls upon the occasion of their marriage and when they take up housekeeping in their own homes. Please state whether these girls live at home with their parents or with whom they reside, and the reserve on which they are located. Do these girls intend to be married in the near future? Our funds this year are extremely limited, and until we are assured that proper care would be taken of the machines and that they would not be used indiscriminately by other parties, we would not be prepared to supply same.

Regarding the set of carpenter tools for Charley Johnson, you might also state whether this boy would make good use of the tools, and the approximate cost of same, also where he resides.

When we have this information, consideration will be given as to whether funds can be provided this year or not.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

H. E. Taylor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Williams Lake, B.C.
Sir:

I have acknowledged receipt of your letter of Sept. 15th last relative to the supplying of sewing machines to ex-pupils of the Caribee Indian Residential School, and a set of carpenter tools to ex-pupil No. 171 Charley Thomas Johnson.

In regard to the last named, this boy lives on the Alkali Lake Indian Reserve and his father is handyman on the adjoining ranch of Mr. Wyman Johnson, having worked there for many years. The boy will be working with his father and will have ample opportunity to use his most decided aptitude for carpentering work. He made great progress in such work whilst at school. The large church erected by the Alkali Lake Band three years ago, and their improved dwellings show that some of this band have availed their carpentering knowledge to material advantage, and a set of carpentering tools costing approximately $35.00 would, I am satisfied, encourage this ex-pupil to carry on the training he has already received.

Regarding the request for sewing machines for the three girl ex-pupils, these are not yet married and it is not known if they contemplate matrimony in the near future. The Reverend Principal recommends that the matter of supplying them with sewing machines be left in abeyance for the present and he recommends that machines be supplied to ex-pupils No. 132 of Williams Lake Indian Band and No. 209 Ellen Jeane of the Canoe Creek Band. These two girls were discharged last year and are now both married. They were excellent pupils whilst at school and received no reward. It would appear advisable to give sewing machines upon the Principal's recommendation when ex-pupils are married and established in homes, instead of supplying them at discharge. The names of those recommended upon discharge this year will be kept on record and applications made upon their behalf at a later date upon marriage, if their circumstances warrant their receiving sewing machines.

Your obedient servant,

H. W. Taylor
Indian Agent

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Ottawa, October 15, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the supplying of a set of carpentering tools for ex-pupil No. 171, Charlie Thomas Johnson, and sewing machines for two girl ex-pupils, Nos. 0209 and 0152, and stating the present circumstances in the case of each.

You may arrange for the purchase, from a firm on the list to receive consideration, of a set of carpentering tools at a cost not to exceed approximately $35, and have them delivered to Charlie Thomas Johnson. Please forward an itemized account, in triplicate, covering the cost. This you should attach to a proper voucher form, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Regarding the request for sewing machines for the two girls referred to above, I regret that, as our funds this year for assistance to ex-pupils have been considerably reduced, we will be unable to provide the expenditure required in applying each with a sewing machine. You might draw the attention of the Department to their case next year, when, if funds are available, consideration would be given to supplying each with a machine.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I am dead.

Promised through the Dept a sewing machine (singer) supplied upon the occasion of my marriage & decision to take up housekeeping on my own account.

So after my marriage I wrote to the agent W.J. Ferguson

Telling him that my name & name was Mrs J.M. Mason (formerly Miss Rossiter)

And that I wished to receive my machine as I had already received my paper diploma.

In reply I received a refusal from the school.

Saying that J.M. Mason was not an Indian and therefore he had lost all my rights.

I have heard that he has been putting a lot of Indians money in his own pocket.

So now I suspect he has also used the money I allowed me for machine along with the rest of the peoples money.

He has been keeping Indians here with relief as low as $1.05 per month.

People that have a family of four plus six children. And people who have nothing but are bachelors all getting $1.05 per month.

Rev. and dear Father,

I cannot explain how glad I am to write you these few lines to let you know that I am still alive and enjoying a happy and healthy life. Alfred and the two little children are alright. Alexander Daniel and Rosy Louisa.

I hope you are enjoying good health too. I was sorry I was sorry I wasn't here when you were here yesterday we just came here today poor Clara died yesterday.

Well Father I would like to ask for a sewing machine would you kindly help me to get one I would
like to have one as I always live up at the meadow and cannot have the use of anybody's either. I hope Rev. Father Forbes does not mind me asking you because he the superior of the Mission you were the Superior when I was there. I hope he will be kindly help me too. I will be very thankfull if I can get one I am indeed in need of one.

Everything seems nice around the world and there is nobody sick now at Alkali Lake.

Well I guess I must close my hoping to hear from you soon.

Love regards and fond Good bye

I remain

your respectfully,

Mrs Isabel Alfred Landy.

Dear Sir;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th inst. enclosing letter received from Mrs Edward John of the Canim Lake Indian Band.

This girl was a pupil in the Cariboo Indian Residential School, and left in 1928. At that time the School principal used to ask the Department to supply sewing machines as rewards to leaving pupils, and the machines were shipped direct to the School. Of late years I have had any such machines shipped to me and they are given direct to the pupils.

I consulted Rev. Father Rohr today about this matter and he stated as follows: Rosie Archie, now Mrs Edward John, gave some trouble when in school and it was not thought that she deserved a new sewing machine. Father Rohr was School Principal at the time, and the Sister Superior advised me that the girl had been given the machine which she had worked with in her last year at school. The machine was in good working order. A year or two later Rosie Archie complained that the machine was no good, but it was thought that she had broken it. However they had it repaired for her and put into working order. Last year the girl wrote to Father Rohr and he referred the matter to the present School principal, who advises me that he asked the travelling Singer Machine representative to call in at the Reserve and fix the machine if necessary. The Principal does not know if this was done.

I recall some four or five years ago that when visiting the Canim Lake reserve, Rosie Archie asked me to get her some needles for the machine, which I did. This would show that it was then in use, and at that time she made no complaint to me.

I think it probable that this girl resented being given a second-hand machine when she saw some of the other pupils receiving new ones. In other matters I have found her very prone to complain.

I am returning the letter herewith.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:-

With reference to Mr. Indian Agent Taylor's letter of March 31st, I may say that, where funds permit, I am certainly in favour of girls graduating from our Indian Residential Schools being provided upon marriage with a Singer sewing machine. I refer, of course, to those graduates who have made proper use of their Vocational Training while in School and are recommended by their Principals for the Department's favourable consideration in this matter.

I would, therefore, recommend that a Singer sewing machine be given to each of the following ex-pupils of the Cariboo Indian Residential School:-

Mrs. Walter Gaspard, Canoe Creek
" Pat. Chalchel, Alkali Lake.
" Felix Stump, Anaham.

I believe that, should the Department decide to provide properly-qualified ex-pupils with such sewing machines, and to those boys who have done well in Manual Training while at School with a small kit of tools and possibly enough lumber to build a simple house, a great impetus would be given to Vocational and Manual Training in our Residential Schools.

If you and the Director of Welfare and Training agree with me in this matter, I would request that Indian Agents and the Principals of the various Indian Residential Schools be informed of the Department's policy. To encourage the children at present in the Indian Residential Schools, it would, of course, be necessary for the Principals concerned to inform the pupils of the Department's policy.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C.

Dear Sir:

You may recall discussing with me last year the matter of awards to pupils who graduate from the Cariboo Indian Residential School, and suggesting that one boy and one girl might be selected each year to receive something from the Department.

I am now advised by the Rev. Principal that the staff of the School have chosen the following:

From the Graduating Class of 1939:
#0250 - Mary Violet Mouse - Williams Lake Reserve
#206 - Gilbert Nelson - Alkali Lake Reserve

From the Graduating Class of 1940:
#0269 - Ethel Baptiste - Alexandria Reserve
#240 - Eddie Henry Dick - Anaham Reserve.

If it is considered advisable to defer giving sewing machines to the girls until they have married, I do not know what procedure would be followed. It might happen that, after a few years, several girls would marry during the same year and all be eligible for machines.

If you think funds might be available to give something to the above two boys, I would ask them if they preferred harness or tools or some other suitable award.

I do not wish to broach the matter to them until I am assured that something can be given to them.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that I have received a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Christie endorsing the following recommendation made by the Reverend Father Murphy, O.M.I., ex principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School, for awards to outstanding pupils of the 1942 graduation class, just prior to his departure from the school for a charge in Eastern Canada.

"That No. 0276 Phyllis Sellars as the best and most efficient girl student of her class and No. 276 Walter Allan Paul as the best and most efficient boy and that the most useful articles the Department could supply these ex-pupils would be a sewing machine for the girl and a set of carpenters' tools for the boy."

Mr. Christie advises that Walter Allan Paul is exceptionally handy as a carpenter and it may be possible to work him in at the construction of the new Air Base at Dog Creek.

I should appreciate being advised if funds are available for this purpose.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa,
September 1, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Phyllis Sellars and Walter Allan Paul

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 27th ultimo, in which you state that you have received a recommendation from the Rev. Father Murphy, Principal of the Cariboo School, that assistance be granted to the above-noted pupils.

You are authorized to purchase, from firms on the approved list, one sewing machine for Phyllis Sellars and a set of carpenter's tools for Walter Allan Paul.

I feel it is only fair to point out that it may not be possible for the Department to make these purchases at any time in the future. We have recently been informed by the Purchasing Agent that it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure supplies, particularly metal supplies. It might be well, therefore, for us to have an understanding with the Principals of these schools that such assistance would not be recommended by them during the war period.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Coal for Bella Bella Indian Day School

During the past two years the following difficulties have been encountered in getting the coal fuel delivered to the above named School:

1. Shortage of labour to handle coal in September and October, the Indians not being back from the Canneries.

2. Shortage of coal in September and October and the inability of Evans, Coleman & Evans to supply the order before January.

3. Due to (2) above, extreme difficulty in getting the empty sacks back for credit and consequent delay in getting accounts vouchered before close of the fiscal year.

To overcome these difficulties it is recommended that the coal for the 1946-47 year be put in in May which should be (1) the slack season for delivery (2) the month when we are sure of Indian labour.

May the following order be placed as soon as funds are available:

Fifteen (15) tons, Nanaimo-Wellington coal in 100 lb. sacks, to be delivered by first available steamer after receipt of order to Indian Day School, Hospital Dock, Campbell Island, B.C. freight prepaid. Invoices in triplicate to be mailed together with prepaid freight vouchers to Indian Agent, Dept. Mines & Resources, Bella Coola, B. C.

It costs $2.75 a ton for delivery from wharf to coal cellar, the emptying and return of sacks ready for shipment and the moving back of coal to get entire shipment inside. A sum of $41.25 will be required for this purpose and authority to incur this expenditure is requested.

(over)
If sanctioned, an accountable cheque to cover these costs will be required.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ontario.

Upon inspection of Indian Day Schools at Bella Coola, I find that the wood supply will not last beyond the end of the calendar year.

Eleven and one-half cords of furnace wood were delivered to the schools last March. Ostensibly this was for the current school year but I have been informed that because of extreme weather last spring, this supply was already in use by April.

Due to this and also to the fact that a second (separate) school room is now in use, the eleven and one-half cords were certainly not adequate for both schools. I estimate that eight cords furnace wood will be necessary for both rooms to complete the school year.

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Prince Rupert, B.C.

I have your voucher No. 434 in favour of Philpott, Evitt and Company Ltd., covering the supply of coal to the Metlakatla Indian Day School during the month of April, at a cost of $19.10. This expenditure was not authorized by this office nor is there anything on the voucher to indicate that it was authorized by the Department.

It is realized that the supply of coal to Indian Day Schools and teacherages is necessary but there would appear to be no reason why you could not first apply for authority for the expenditure. It would be preferable to make one submission covering fuel requirements for all schools in your Agency at one time. Your voucher is being forwarded to the Department and recommended for payment.

D. M. MacKay,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Fuel for teacherage,
Bella Coola Indian Day School

The teachers of the above named school have applied to me for fuel, since they state advertisements have appeared in the press from time to time advertising positions in Indian Day schools in this province and stating remuneration at rates equal to those being paid here and including quarters, fuel and light.

Mrs. Snodgrass lives in the building which is rented by the department and her annual requirements would be about five cords of twelve inch wood at $12.00 per cord delivered; plus one ton of coal approximately $25.00 delivered, or a total of around $85.00 per year.

Miss Wright has built her own house but has asked for help with fuel. She burns oil and uses sixteen barrels per year. In view of having her own establishment Miss Wright has asked that consideration be given to supplying one half of her fuel or eight barrels, (360 gallons) at around twenty cents per gallon including drayage or $72.00 total.

The total involved would therefore be about $157.00 per year. No item for this expenditure appears in the 1947-48 Estimates, neither did I make provision to that extent in the 1948-49 Estimates although the teacherage was included in the heading to the column setting forth school fuel requirements. I had anticipated that Mrs. Snodgrass might apply for aid in fuel for the teacherage building and I had included the item of four cords of twelve inch wood with this in view.

(over)
It now appears that my estimate was inadequate even for the teacherage alone. I had not made enquiries since I did not wish to raise the point until a policy had been settled. No provision in the estimates were made for fuel allowance for Miss Wright.

May I have your decision on this matter and authority for expenditure if approved.

[Signature]

W.F. Pruden,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Fuel for teacherage - Bella Coola
Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. Indian Agent Pruden's letter of November 5th attached hereto, our files do not indicate that the Department has been previously called upon to provide fuel for teacherages at the Bella Coola school, but as we supply fuel for teacherages elsewhere it is felt that we should be consistent. Under the circumstances it is recommended that an expenditure of $157.00 be approved for the purchase of fuel for the buildings occupied by Mrs. Snodgrass and Miss Wright.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

December 4th, 1947

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Coal - Bella Bella Day School

Your 2-11-1 of October 2nd did not arrive here in time for me to get a message to Mr. R. Carpenter who had offered to move our coal free of charge on his seine boat if it arrived before he left for the southern seining ground. He had already gone and has been away ever since, being engaged in herring seining now. The coal arrived and was unloaded at B. C. Packers wharf across the channel from the village. Martin's wharf which is in poor condition would not carry the load. However costs would have been about the same from Martin's.

As there were only gillnet boats available I made arrangements with a local native to move it. This meant carrying it down the ramp at B. C. Packers, stowing what he could in his boat, crossing to the reserve, wading ashore and wheeling the coal by wheel barrow to the school. He asked fifty cents a sack which I considered reasonable.

Somehow I had gathered from your 2-11-1 of October 20th that only five tons would be sent until the Hospital wharf was completed. On re-reading it now I realize that you had probably not intended that meaning. In any case on my last visit to Bella Bella on the evening of November 20th, I was told that two large shipments of coal had arrived since the first one. We were unable to count the sacks in the dark but I assumed our whole order had arrived and was occupying considerable space on the B. C. Packers wharf. I therefore made arrangements with the same native to continue his former arrangement for the whole lot. Miss Broeker will count the sacks as they arrive at the school.

(over)
My request for funds (8-11-7 of August 2nd) assumed labor only from the Hospital wharf, at twenty-cents per sack. I will therefore require an additional thirty cents per sack or $90.00 for transporting the coal from B.C. Packers wharf to the school house.

May accountable cheque be issued for $90.00 to cover this item of expense.

With reference to the attached voucher for one half ton of coal for use in the teacher's residence at Kitamaat village, authority for fuel 45-162-W.T.I of Nov. 22/47 authorized purchase of fuel oil for this teacherage. The shipment of oil received in January was of very poor quality. Mr. Robinson found that it could not be used in his cook stove and the oil burner was removed and grates replaced in order to burn other fuel. He bought and paid for a half ton of coal himself.

When I visited Kitamaat he took this up with me and asked whether he would thus be allowed to change from oil to coal. I assured him that under the circumstances I was sure his action would be approved.

I therefore recommend that the amount be refunded to Mr. Robinson.

The substantial increase over 1947-48 year and over estimates prepared last June is the result of experience in endeavoring to put in wood stocks during the past year. There was widespread complaint that prices were far too low and great difficulty was experienced in getting any wood cut, except at Bella Coola where Indians from the interior were glad of this work during their annual visit to the coast and where motor transport is available.

Only a mild winter saved the schools at Bella Bella, Klemtu and Kitamaat from serious privation. At the latter point where a wood furnace is installed, only seven cords were finally delivered in March after being on order from the previous May. The balance of the wood was not delivered and this resulted in having to order in small quantities of coal from Butedale cannery at heavy transportation costs to cover emergencies. In addition, observation has shown me that for a severe winter fuel requirements in wood as set up last year would be inadequate. I have therefore increased the amounts substantially and raised the price. With the location of this school necessitating heavy freight costs, I believe every effort should be made to use as much wood as possible and I have decided to try for one more year to put in an adequate wood supply before changing over to coal.

In the case of Bella Bella the amount of kindling remains the same but the unit price has been advanced. Wood at this point comes from drift logs which often must be towed considerable distances, cut on the beach and then transported by wheel barrow one half mile up hill or more to the school house. Conditions at Klemtu are about the same as at Bella Bella. The amount has been increased to partly replace the oil which was formerly burned in the teacherage.

At Bella Coola, quantities for the schools remain the same with prices increased for cedar as I found the Indians who cut the wood did not do well last year as cedar is not readily accessible. An item of increase over last years requirements is represented by the five cords for the teacherage which is now being supplied.

May accountable advance of $929.00 be supplied to enable the placing of wood orders at an early date.

Regarding fire wood requirements for schools of this Agency for the fiscal year 1949-50, owing to the work habits of the people of this agency, it has proved impossible to obtain wood cutters from about mid April each year when activity in fishing commences. There are few men in the villages until about mid November when trapping commences and time must be taken to prepare their own families for winter. Although it may sometimes be possible to have a little wood cut any time from November on during the winter, it has been found that the only time this work is sought by the natives is from about March 1st until mid April and then only on the understanding of fairly prompt settlement. The fiscal policy of returning all funds to Ottawa during March makes it impossible to take advantage of the one time in the year when there are men more or less willing to cut wood. Funds drawn during the new fiscal year usually do not arrive until about June. By which time the villages are empty of people.

Would it be possible to have the funds for 1949-50 school wood requirements sent down now when an effort will be made to get as much of the wood in as possible during the winter. It will probably not be possible to expend the whole amount until late in April. Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have today received a communication from Mr. Anfield, Indian Agent, Bella Coola, within which was enclosed a copy of his letter of May 16th re Gordon Robinson of Kitimat, which was addressed to you.

I should like to state that I was unable to visit Kitimat at the time that Mr. Anfield and I made our original plans to go in to the village, and I have therefore, not seen Robinson. However, I feel that the plan proposed by Mr. Anfield is of such merit that I am going to make every effort to visit Robinson before the end of June.

I may say that I would quite readily endorse the principle suggested in Mr. Anfield's letter to you. The idea of having a married couple, adequately trained, act as leaders in a village has been discussed by Mr. Gillett and myself on many occasions. The plan has been successful in remote and also in backward areas, as well as in more progressive areas.

I have suggested to Mr. Anfield that I think it would be a good plan to postpone formal action on this matter until I have an opportunity of speaking to Mr. Lord, principal of the Normal School, and Dr. Willis, Superintendent of Education. I expect that I shall be able to see these men late in June and I shall communicate with you again after that time.

Yours truly,

B. Thorsteinsson

F. E. Anfield, Esq., Indian Agent, Bella Coola, B.C.

Acknowledging receipt of your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the proposal that we apply to have Gordon Robinson of Kitamaat admitted to Normal School, I would advise that as he has only passed Grade X in an Indian Residential School it would not appear that he would have the necessary educational standard to permit the Department of Education to accede to the request, notwithstanding Inspector Thorsteinsson's endorsement. It is unfortunate that this young man did not take advantage of the Provincial Correspondence Courses to bring his standard up to at least Junior Matriculation, which would then, of course, clear the way for his admission. However, the matter has been submitted to the Superintendent of Education for consideration.

I am extremely anxious that we take no action or suggest that such action be taken to lower the standards of qualifications of persons teaching in Indian schools. I personally feel that we require even higher standards than would a Provincial rural school. However, you will be advised further in the matter in due course.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.
Re: Gordon Robinson, Teacher, Kitamaat Indian Day School

The above named Indian was appointed teacher pro tem in December 1944 at the Kitamaat Indian Day School. He is twenty-seven years of age, married with two young children.

He has done exceptionally well and has the makings of a real teacher. He enjoys good health as does his wife and both are athletically inclined. They have good standing as Indians and are highly respected among their people.

Gordon Robinson has expressed the wish to go to Normal School this winter and train as a teacher. I believe he would make a success of such a course if arrangements can be made to admit him as a special student training for Indian school work only.

He is a first class athlete and has a fine collection of trophies in his home from school sports whilst at Coqualeetza. I would like to see him combine his course at Normal with a course in Pro-Rec training so that when he returned to his village he could put this Pro-Rec programme into the lives of his people. If it were possible for his wife to go to Vancouver or Victoria as well, she could have the women's course in Pro-Rec as well and thus have a Pro-Rec team for both sexes in Kitamaat.

In Kitamaat morale is low, due in large measure to lack of trained leadership. The Church has had no missionary with a youth viewpoint for some years and it is my firm conviction that in Robinson and his wife, we have the possibility of social reconstruction for this very isolated village.

Educationally this young man has completed Grade X and it will be necessary to secure special permission to admit him as a Normal student. I attach a copy of his Grade X marks.

If the Normal School will take him, it will be necessary for him to obtain financial assistance in the form a grant as an ex-pupil of a Residential School to meet the expenses of a year in Normal. A condition of any such grant should be an agreement by Robinson to teach at Kitamaat Day School for a stated period of years, say three at least. I would estimate that a grant of $600.00 would be required for the ten months course and I consider it would be money well spent in every way.
The third and perhaps most difficult problem would be the securing of living quarters in either Vancouver or Victoria, depending on which Normal School he would be allocated to attend. I believe wholeheartedly that in this matter, the United Church through Rev. W.P. Bunt, would give very real assistance indeed.

To sum up: (1) Gordon Robinson wishes to train as a teacher. (2) He has in my opinion, the makings of a very good teacher and he should be encouraged and assisted to secure training. (3) A trained male Indian teacher (especially a married one with family) with added Pro-Rec training is the real need for Kitamaat Indian Village and he would be worth more to the village, the Church and the Department, than most of the white female teachers we have had in the past few years. (4) I am convinced that the Indians will never solve their problems (nor will we for them) until they can produce their own leaders, teachers, nurses, etc. In Robinson we have material on which to start such a programme as far as this Agency is concerned.

It is therefore recommended, if you approve of the plan in principle, that (a) a conference be held with the Principal of the Normal School and Rev. W. P. Bunt to decide whether or not this young man would be accepted in Normal School and on what terms; (I would recommend that no certificate be requested for him until by subsequent summer school courses he has earned them) and whether he and his family could be housed in Vancouver or Victoria. (b) If these matters can be settled satisfactorily, that the Department be requested to make a direct grant of at least $600.00 towards his tuition and expenses (c) if at all possible, it is urged that Mr. Jerry Mathison, Prov. Director of Pro-Rec be included in the conference suggested above.

For years the Indians have been pleading for a chance to have their young people given opportunities of leadership of this kind. The one obstacle has always been lack of suitably educated personnel to take such training. I think we have a suitable man in Gordon Robinson and I wholeheartedly recommend that the entire situation be surveyed with a sympathetic determination to try and give him an opportunity to receive a Normal and Pro-Rec training, which I firmly believe he has the ability and character to absorb and put to use for his people.

F.E. Anfield,
Indian Agent.

P.S. Mrs. Evans, the present teacher at Kitsmaat endorses the plan for Gordon and has promised to carry on next year at this School. By that time Gordon should be ready to take over the School.

Copy for Inspector B. Thorsteinsson.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith a file of correspondence between this office, the Bella Coola Agency and the Department of Education with reference to the proposal of Mr. Indian Agent Anfield for admission of Gordon Robinson, an Indian of the Kitimat Band, at present the junior teacher at the school on that Reserve, to Normal School training, requesting Departmental assistance of $600.00 in order that he may returned to the Reserve and take charge of the Kitimat Indian Day School. It will be noted that he is strongly recommended for this course by the Indian Agent and the School Inspector of the locality and that the Department of Education have approved of his entry to Normal School notwithstanding his lack of academic qualification.

Under the circumstances I would recommend consideration of the application by Department on the basis of an outright non-repayable grant of $300.00 and a repayable grant of a further $300.00, repayment to be spread over three years and recovered from his teacher's salary at the rate of $10.00 a month for the ten school months of each academic year. Further that he be required to undertake to teach at Kitimaat or some other day school for the three year period covered by the loan, subject to the right of the Department to dispense with his services in the usual way.

You will note from my letter of the 30th ultimo to Indian Agent Anfield that I was not entirely satisfied with the young man's academic standing and his failure to attempt to qualify for Junior Matriculation by correspondence course. I have, however, in mind the unwarranted
criticism that has been leveled at the Department for alleged failure to provide advanced education for worthy Indians.

Please airmail your reply as the Normal School opens on September 10th and due to the inaccessibility of Kitimaat mail service to that point is uncertain.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, June 26, 1945.

AIR MAIL

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for BC.
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, enclosing correspondence with reference to the proposal of Indian Agent Anfield to assist Gordon Robinson, of the Kitamaat Band, to attend Normal School during the academic year 1945-46.

I have discussed your letter with Mr. Hoey this afternoon and we are inclined to feel that the amount of $600.00 is excessive. Possibly, in asking for this amount, Robinson is endeavouring to obtain funds for the maintenance of his family while he is absent at the Normal School. There is the further consideration that there is no guarantee that he will be successful in taking the course that is proposed. We do not view with any favour the suggestion that part of the grant be made refundable.

However, in spite of the above, we have no desire to hinder this man from attending normal school if our assistance is sufficient. Evidently Indian Agent Anfield believes that he will take full advantage of the course, but, if he starts, I definitely feel that monthly reports regarding his progress should be obtained from the Principal of the Normal School, in order that we may be assured that he is studying. In the event of his taking the course, we are prepared to allow an outright grant of $500.00 for the academic year 1945-46. If he accepts this offer, it should be further provided that
he would undertake to teach the Kitamaat or some other day school for two years following his successful completion of the course, subject, of course, to the right of the Department to dispense with his services, if we so desired.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

"You wrote me some time ago concerning Gordon Robinson and I promised to let you know how he progressed in his Practicum.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B. C.

Two boys, Cecil Reid and Taylor Brown of this Agency have made application for high school tuition grants. These boys have done exceptionally well at St. Michael's school, Alert Bay, and Mr. Wickens recommends that they receive further high school education. They completed Grade IX and are ready to enter Grade X.

Unfortunately, due to the fact that preliminary arrangements with reference to these boys were being conducted from the Skeena River Agency, the necessary correspondence only reached me on August 29th. With the opening of the 1946-47 school term but a week away, I made inquiries by wire as to their admission to Langley Prairie High School and as to a boarding house.

The principal of the school replied accepting the boys for Grade X and Mrs. Askil Johnson, who boarded two boys from the Skeena River Agency last year, has also signified her willingness to take both boys.

The estimated cost for the academic year for each boy is as follows:

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| Tuition for ten months      | $50.00 |
| Text books                  | $20.00 |
| Board for ten months        | $30.00 |
| **Total**                   | **$370.00** |

Each boy has deposited in the Bella Coola Agency Trust account the sum of $150.00 as their share of cost of board. It is recommended that the Department approve a grant of $220.00 for each boy, being one-half the cost of board, plus tuition fees and books.

(over)
I may add that Taylor Brown's parents have furnished the money for their son's schooling, but that great credit is to be given Cecil Reid who worked at Nemu Cannery all summer in order to finance his share, when he found his family not overly receptive to spending money to further his education.

Due to the urgency in having them start the school year on time, I have instructed both boys to proceed to Langley High School.

I trust my action will be approved and strongly recommend that the grant requested by me be made.

Enclosed in duplicate are forms 502-1 and 502-2 being application for tuition grant and physical examinations. Also enclosed is average scholastic standing for each boy as they completed Grade IX at Alert Bay Residential School.
