Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Rowena Ross - aged 18

The above named young Indian woman was attending High School from Alberni Residential School last year. She has completed Grade X and for the past year has determined to continue and complete Grade XII with a view to taking up the nursing profession as a career. Mr. Caldwell has spoken very highly of her and from my own observation I would recommend her most highly.

Some doubt existed this spring that her father would assist her with clothing etc. for the current year at High School. I saw the father, Samuel Ross in August and he agreed to give Rowena the necessary aid as her earnings at the cannery this summer were not adequate to fit her out. However it appears that at the last moment Samuel Ross withdrew his support and Rowena was unable to leave for Alberni in time to start the high school term in September. When I visited Butedale late that month I found her still there and still determined to carry through her intention. A half sister had offered her a home at Kitamaat for the winter and she had written for a correspondence course for Grade XII. I suggested to her that she might do better working at one of the Indian Health Service hospitals as a ward aide and cover her correspondence course in her off hours under supervision of the teacher at the hospital. Dr. Tennant was good enough to place Rowena at the Nanaimo hospital. She has gone down there and is established.

I now have a letter from her from which I quote as follows:

"I just received a letter from Dr. Lucus of the Correspondence Dept. and they're going to forward me the application forms. Do you think the Indian Dept. could pay the cost of my books? They pay for the books that the high school students in Alberni are using, so I don't see why they can't do that for me. I haven't received my books yet. Will you see what you can do, Mr. Pruden? Because you see I have very little money myself. I didn't earn much at the close of the fishing season. What I did earn went to the expense of my ward aide's uniforms and shoes and my fare."

(over)
I still have to buy two more uniforms. I've appreciated all you've done for me and I will try my very best to work hard and study.

It is my intention that should Rowena be successful this year in completing her Grade XI by correspondence to recommend that she be given full maintenance next year to attend a regular high school and complete her Grade XII. It seems that no help can be expected from her father who appears unable to grasp the importance of his daughter's higher education.

I would recommend that a grant be given sufficient to provide books for the Grade XI correspondence course. To save time, would it be possible for Major Davie to send the books direct to Rowena Ross at the Nanaimo Indian hospital.

I am writing Rowena to suggest that she save as much as possible from her wages during the next ten months in order that she have some money for clothing etc., for next year. I am also telling her that she will be advised from your office whether it is possible to assist her with books this year.

P. Pruden,
Indian Agent.
Alberni Indian Residential School

Alberni, B.C.

Nov. 17th 1947.

Major D.M. MacKey,
Commissioner, Indian Affairs,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re Rowena Ross, former pupil

Dear Major MacKey,

I have yours of the 14th inst. re Rowena Ross, a pupil who passed grade 10 in the Alberni high School last year, but who did not return after the vacation to continue her studies, apparently because she could not finance the return fare. Subsequently she became employed at the Nanaimo Hospital as Nurse's Aid.

Rowena's intention is to take nursing training. From her aptitude, it is my opinion that she can succeed in her ambition. I agree that she could not take grade XI by correspondence while continuing her present occupation.

Her record in this school is good, and her reports from the Alberni High School were also good. I have taken her case up with Mr. Dunn the Principal of the Alberni High School, particularly as to her taking up Grade XI after losing two months of the term. Mr. Dunn thinks that Rowena has sufficient ability to catch up with the other pupils and he is willing to take her as soon as she can be sent back to school.

While we are full in pupil requirement at the residential school, we can always make room for another, especially as some good purpose might be served.

Yours very truly,

"A.E. Caldwell"

Principal.

With reference to Mr. Indian Agent Pruden's letter of March 22nd attached, you will note that the per capita cost to the Langley Municipality for students attending the Langley High School is $84.48 and that the Secretary is requesting payment of tuition costs for the six Indian children of the Bella Coola Agency at the rate of $80.00 each per annum.

The Department has already approved payment of tuition fees at the rate of $50.00 per annum for these six pupils and I would recommend that the additional funds necessary be made available when the Municipality submits their account.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Bella Coola, B. C.,
March 22nd, 1948.

Mr. W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Cecil Reid Bella Bella Band
Taylor Brown "
Beverley Mason "
Doris Hall "
Kenneth Windsor "
James Mack Bella Coola Band

The above named Indians are students at Langley High School. I have received a letter from the secretary of the school from which I quote as follows:

"The per capita cost to the Municipality for High School students has been worked out as follows:

Net cost of maintaining the Langley Jr.-Sr. High School during 1947 . . . . . . . . $43,000.00;

Average enrollment of pupils during 1947 . . . .509

Therefore, $\frac{43,000}{509} = \$84.48$, or the annual net per capita cost per student.

In connection with the above, please be advised that the tuition fees authorized for students attending the Langley Jr.-Sr. High School, will be henceforward, $80.00 per annum.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) L.V.K. Mercer
Secretary"

Apparently these costs are based purely on maintenance and no account is taken of capital investment. It therefore appears that the amount of $80.00 is most reasonable as a per capita tuition fee for Indian children attending this school.

(over)
Estimates submitted when grants were requested for the above named students anticipated a charge of $50.00 per student as in the past term.

May the grant in case of each of the above named pupils be increased by $30.00 to care for accounts from this school when they arrive at the end of the term.

W.P. Pruden,
Indian Agent.

I have received a request from Gordon W. Robinson, Indian of the Kitamaat Band, and teacher at the Kitamaat Indian Day School, for assistance in the amount of $100.00 to enable him to attend the Shurpass School, Vancouver, during the summer months.

Mr. W. S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

During the past three years we have had a number of Indian students in attendance at our school and have found them willing to work into our school and further found that they have been accepted by our students. This acceptance went so far that the Student's Council wrote to our local Member of Parliament in the last part of June of this year requesting that Indians of our province be given the vote.

I understand from Mr. W. F. Pruden, Superintendent of the Bella Coola Indian Agency that he has recommended that Kenneth Windsor and James Mack continue their schooling although both of these boys did not complete Grade IX here at our school last year. These lads came into Grade VIII much older than their classmates simply because they did not start school at the same time. I do feel that the year of orientation which they obtained here last year will make them better citizens and that any Intelligent Quotient Tests which we could give would not be a fair estimate of their innate ability. My reason for feeling this is that these boys no doubt are aware of many things in nature and in fishing and other things that cannot be measured in routine Intelligent Quotient tests. Further their vocabulary hinders them from actually completing tests of this character.
Mr. W. S. Arneil

I understand that James intends to return to school at Bella Coola and feel that the grounding which he received here should enable him to get his year. I understand further that Ken Windsor will not be able to return unless he has aid from your department and that the policy of your Department is not to grant assistance unless a student passes. I appreciate this policy but do feel that there are, perhaps, exceptions. Ken is not an outstanding student nor ever will he be. I do feel, however, that another year at Langley High School will definitely, with our new Industrial Arts Programme help him to be a useful citizen in his own community later.

Very truly yours,

R. R. Brunt
Supervising Principal

Re: Tuition Grants

Replying to your S-11-1 of August 26th, Langley High School where most of the students attended last year do not issue individual report cards. However Mr. Brunt, the principal, has supplied me with the marks of the pupils who attended there last year and a copy of his report is attached herewith.

Since I wrote you, Beverley Mason has decided to remain at home during the coming term. No grant will be required in her case. This is unfortunate as indications were that this student had qualities that would have fitted her as a school teacher in the judgement of her teachers of last term.

Taylor Brown, Cecil Reid and Doris Hall have successfully passed into the next higher grade as indicated by the report. They will be attending and deposits of share of board money have been made with this office to cover the year, Taylor Brown having deposited $150.00 and Doris Hall $100.00. The deposit from Cecil Reid has been promised and is expected in an early mail.

One new student will be attending Langley High School from the Bella Bella Band as noted in my earlier letter. Peter Mason will be taking Grade IX, the technical course, having passed from Grade VIII at Bella Bella Day School last term. The report for this student is in your office. I have not received a copy. Will you therefore submit details to the Department as required.

Regarding Kenneth Windsor who failed to pass to a higher grade last term, on my last tour of the Agency and before your letter arrived it was necessary to complete all details for pupils leaving for High School in order that they be at school on time. I collected $150.00 from Kenneth Windsor as his share of the board money for the coming year on the understanding that the Department would take care of the additional costs as set out in my letter of recommendation. I realize that I was acting without full authority in this instance, however as I see these students only once each year and a rendezvous had been arranged to settle details for the coming term, and since Kenneth is working on a seine fishing boat and will leave his work at the last possible moment to join some steamer going south, it would be difficult to cancel the arrangement. I believe also that this case warrants further consideration. In my discussion with Mr. Brunt, Principal of the Langley High School, he referred to Kenneth Windsor and James Mack as cases that although they both had failed to pass to the higher grade, nevertheless he felt that they had done very well in view of the problem of reorientation with which they had been faced. Coming as they did from the reserve environment of their homes and the Residential School, a great deal had been required of them that other pupils do not face. No technical course was available last year and Mr. Brunt felt that a better showing might have been made in technical subjects. He urged that both of these boys be allowed to continue their studies as he felt the past year's failure was not indicative of their possibilities.

(over)
I am writing to Mr. Brunt asking that he express his views in a letter direct to you. Without help, I do not believe it will be possible for Kenneth to continue at school. His share earnings as a crew member on the fishing boat this year have been small. His father will have to aid him with travel fares, clothing and pocket money. There are three younger children and an older sister still in this home in addition to his mother and father. In view of the urgent need for the development of leaders among the native people and considering that from this agency only about one tenth of the young people who should be in high school are attending now, I feel I must ask that Kenneth Windsor be afforded aid so I have recommended for the coming term and will appreciate a reconsideration of this matter. In the mean time he will be attending school. Should a decision be made against this grant then to save time and additional expense, I would appreciate your office making direct contact with Kenneth at the Langley High School or at his boarding house, c/o Mrs. A. Smith, 2468 Lee Road, Milner, B.C., and advising him that the Department's aid will not be forthcoming. Mrs. Smith also should be advised since my arrangement with her was on the basis of the department's paying $30.00 each month on Kenneth's board.

Regarding James Mack, I have not yet had a chance to see him or his family since receiving your letter. It is intended that he live at home and attend the Bella Coola High School. I believe it is possible his father may be willing to finance his tuition fees and books for this year. I have received a letter from the Ocean Falls School Board agreeing to the attendance of James Mack in Grade IX. Mary Hall in Grade VII or VIII and Dennis Snow in Grade VI at the Bella Coola Provincial School. I have not yet been advised what tuition fees will be required.

In accordance with verbal arrangement made with Mr. Davey, Percy Campbell from Bella Bella has been sent to Alberni to attend Grade IX, having passed from Grade VIII at Bella Bella Jay School. Thomas Humchitt, who graduated from Grade VIII at Alberni Residential School has returned there to attend Grade IX in Alberni High School. It has been customary for Mr. Caldwell to apply for grants for students attending High School and living at his school. This matter has therefore been left in his hands.

Tuition Grants

We have your letter of the 15th instant, file 2-11-1, with reference to Kenneth Windsor.

We have given very careful consideration to both your letter and the letters from Superintendent Prudent and Mr. Brunt, Supervising Principal of Langley Senior High School.

The following decision has been made regarding Kenneth Windsor:

(a) We are prepared to allow for the period September 1st to December 31st, 1948, an amount of $160.00.

(b) The above allowance is being made on the understanding that his work will be reviewed at the end of December and we will then be in a position to decide if the grant should be continued for the balance of the current academic year.

It should also be understood that we are making the grant mentioned above in view of the information contained in Mr. Brunt's letter to the effect that he will follow the new industrial arts programme instead of the academic course.

In our opinion the correspondence regarding Kenneth Windsor brings up an important question which is that the Department is extremely loath to renew tuition grant in the case of any pupil who is not successful.
It, therefore, follows that extreme care must be exercised by all parties concerned to give the Indian boy or girl careful guidance regarding the course which they should pursue.

In this regard I mean that the boys, especially, should be encouraged to follow industrial courses rather than the straight academic courses, except in isolated instances.

We have also noted the fact that some children are being sent to Alberni Residential School this year in order that they can attend the high school at Alberni. Does this high school offer academic and industrial courses? If so, we believe that Indian pupils should be encouraged to attend this school and live at the Alberni Residential School.

From experience in Ontario and other provinces, better results have been obtained when the pupil resides in a residential school close to the high school. The reasons for extra success in such cases will readily suggest themselves to you.

When you meet any of your Superintendents during the next few months, and when Inspector Davey visits the different agencies in the course of his regular duties, he should discuss the whole situation regarding tuition grants very carefully with each Superintendent.

We are anxious to give deserving Indian children advanced education as far as funds will permit, and at the same time I think you will agree that extreme care must be exercised in order that there will be no waste of public funds.

Another point should be stressed when speaking to Superintendents or others interested in encouraging Indian children to take advanced education and that is that the applications for such assistance should reach head office by August 1st each year.
If this procedure was adopted, there would be time for correspondence and discussion before the new academic year commences. In many cases the applications for tuition grants reach us about September lst. This places head office officials in the unenviable position of either refusing a deserving case or delaying a decision until after the academic year commences.

It is realized that this will be difficult but by constant pressure we should be able to educate our Superintendents to the necessity for following out our wishes as outlined above.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Re: Walter & Margaret Williams

The above named pupils have been attending the Richmond Junior Senior High School for the last two years and the Father, Guy Williams of the Kitimat Band, has borne the total cost of maintaining them in the Richmond Municipality close to the city of Vancouver.

Although Mr. Williams was able to meet this cost in the two preceding years he has not been as successful this year with his fishing and consequently is not able to bear the total cost. He requests that the Department assist him to the extent of $250.00 towards the cost of boarding each of the above mentioned pupils. Mr. Superintendent Pruden has recommend and I concur that this assistance be extended.

It was not possible to anticipate this request as it was hoped that the father would be able to bear the total cost as he has done in the past.

Dept. Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Tuition Grants

Replying to your 42163-3 (E) of February 23rd, attached is revised list of pupils attending Provincial schools from this Agency.

It will be noted that Peter Mason's name has been deleted. This boy left Langley High School on November 20th and returned to his home at Bella Bella. He had been doing quite well at school.

A short time previous to his leaving I had a report that Peter and Kenneth Windsor were not getting enough to eat. I was endeavoring to have this matter investigated when I was informed that Peter had returned home while I was away on an Agency tour. No doubt a factor in his return was that he wished to be present at the wedding of his sister which took place about that time. I wrote Mr. Arneil and reported Peter's action on December 3rd. On December 21st I received a reply suggesting that I interview Peter and report his attitude toward education with a view to his returning to school after the Christmas vacation. At that time I had no opportunity to interview Peter since I was without transportation. I have not yet had the chance to speak to him.

This boy has a good home background. His parents are anxious that he be educated. He was most eager for the opportunity when he went to Langley at first. I believe it should be remembered that the boy had never been out of the "Reserve" orbit before and his action should not be judged too harshly. It was unfortunate that I could not see him soon after his return home. If I find him again eager to return to school and with some evidence of an improved sense of responsibility, I intend to recommend that he be re-admitted to Langley High School next term.

Peter's father is an excellent man, but has a very heavy load financially and I am sure will be unable to finance the boy. During the summer Peter may earn some money himself but could be expected only to pay part of his board. If he is to go to school I will recommend aid similar to that authorized for this term.

(see page two)

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6490, file 42162-3, part 1)
The name of James Mack has also been deleted. After agreeing quite eagerly to attend, he did not put in an appearance. I saw him one week after school opened and talked with him. He appeared quite anxious to go to school but again failed to show up. I was away on a tour of the Agency for three weeks and on my return home found that James was away from the village, having followed the fishing fleet. He had been fishing his own gillnet boat and reluctance to leave this fascinating occupation may have had something to do with his not going to school. I enquired among James' pals and was told in confidence that James had said he would not make any progress at school if he were to live at home where there is a considerable amount of drinking. James felt he would not get the needed rest to pursue his studies.

Before recommending that James attend High School here I had discussed this phase with his father who had agreed that there would be no drinking in the house while James was attending school. He is a man of some character and I accepted his word. He had promised to tell James but now tells me he did not. I have told James' father that I believe that may have been the reason for James' failure to return to school. He has promised to talk to James and if between them they can settle on a plan, then I have agreed to consider James' return to school again. I have little hope in this case.

The name of Thomas Humchitt has also been deleted. For some months I believed he was at Alberni since all arrangements had been made for his departure. I have not received a list of the pupils who are at Alberni. Recently however I was told that Thomas did not return to school last autumn but is at Bella Bella and I am told he is taking a correspondence course at home. I will endeavor to see him when I next visit Bella Bella.

Regarding Taylor Brown, I saw him after his return to Bella Bella and he stated that he did not feel that his progress this year had been satisfactory and felt that if he had remained at school he would have failed. He therefore decided that it was not fair to ask the Department to make further contributions to his education at this time. I might say that he also wished to return to Bella Bella to attend the wedding of his brother who was being married to Peter Mason's sister. However I saw Taylor in mid November and he definitely stated he did not wish to return to school. I believe that Taylor's leaving Langley as he did influenced Peter Mason since Peter left some days after Taylor.

The list as attached is complete as far as I can ascertain. There are of course a great many children in the Agency who are not attending school and it is possible that the parents in some cases may have made private arrangements for some of these.

Last year the school at Butedale took in six native children. I have asked several times for accounts covering their tuition but have not received them. That school is without a teacher this term.

W.P. Pruden,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
Bella Coola, B.C.,

Re: Indian children attending Bella Coola Provincial School

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of August 16th addressed to Mr. Superintendent Pruden.

The pupils attending our own school are enrolled in two separate classrooms, one of which is in our own building and the other being temporarily accommodated in an old building owned by the Indian Band at Bella Coola. As the Provincial School Board increases its accommodation the Indian pupils are being absorbed into the Provincial schools so that within a year or two we will be able to dispense with the most unsatisfactory rented building and also with the services of one of our teachers.

It will be recalled that this is a Protestant Reserve and that there is no likelihood of any objection being made by the church authorities to the admission of Indian children to the Provincial schools. This is also in accordance with the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Indian Affairs.

In view of the poor condition of the one building and the possibility of accommodating grades 4 and above in the Provincial school in the near future, I would suggest that it is advisable not to interfere with the gradual absorption of the Indian pupilage into the Provincial system.

RE: Indian Children Attending Bella Coola, Prov. School

Replying to your 42162-3 (E3) of 16th Aug., 1949. Following are details regarding children attending Bella Coola, Provincial School. All of these children are living on Bella Coola, Indian Reserve #1 and travel to school 8 miles by school bus. Tuition will be about $100.00 each, textbook rental to $5.00 per year, Other Books about $5.00.

Milly (Mary) Hall, Bella Coola Band. Attended Grade 8 at Bella Coola, Provincial School and passed to Grade 9 last year. Held highest average grade for her class. Intends to complete High School and Normal school to qualify as teacher for Indian Schools. Teachers endorse her adaptability to that profession. She was well received by her white classmates and made an excellent adjustment to the new environment. Parents supplying full maintenance except for students earnings as grocery clerk during vacation. Grant needed for tuition & textbooks $105.00.

Wilfred (Dennis) Snow, Bella Coola Band age 15. Completed grade VI and passed to Grade VII, Bella Coola, Provincial School last term. Lives with elderly couple by whom he was adopted Indian fashion. They supply full maintenance. Grant required $105.00 for tuition & textbooks.

David Melkus, of Oweekeno Band, Katit Village, Rivers Inlet. Age 16, attended St. Michaels Indian Residential School, Alert Bay, B.C., in Grade VIII last term. Failed to pass. Principal states this is attributable to poor teaching in 1948 (Gr. VII) when there were five different teachers during the term. Principal spoke highly of this boy both as to character and ability. He was discharged from St. Michaels to make room for younger child. His father is paying full maintenance, including board at Bella Coola but has had a poor fishing year, and I do not believe he can pay for tuition. I recommend a grant of $105.00 for tuition and textbooks in view the report that failure to pass is not a reflection on the ability or industry of the student.

Rhoda Snow, Bella Coola Band age 16. Passed to Grade VII from Bella Coola Indian Day School last term. Parents supplying maintenance. Grant required $105.00 for textbooks & tuition.

Amelia Snow, Bella Coola Band age 14, passed to Grade VI from Bella Coola, Indian Day School last term. Parents supplying maintenance Grant required $105.00 for tuition & Text Books.
Hjordis Mack, Bella Coola Band age 13, passed to Grade VI from Bella Coola Indian Day School last term. Parents supplying maintenance. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

Eliza Mack, Bella Coola Band age 15. Passed to Grade VII from Bella Coola Indian Day School last term. Parents supply maintenance. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

Percy M. Mack, Bella Coola Band age 17. Passed to Grade IX from Alberni Indian Residential School last term. Parents supply maintenance beyond his own earnings as fisherman during summer. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

T. Melvin Mack, Bella Coola Band age 16. Passed to Grade VIII at Alberni Indian Residential School last term. Parents supply maintenance. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

Godfrey B. Tellic, Bella Coola Band age 14. Passed to Grade VII at St Michael's Indian Residential School last term. Grandfather supplies part maintenance. Receiving food relief and will need clothing from welfare funds. Educational Grant required $110.00 to supply tuition, textbooks, and scribblers, pencils and other school supplies.

Arnold Tellic, Bella Coola Band age 14. Passed to Grade VII at St Michael's Indian Residential School last term. Relatives trying to supply maintenance. May need some welfare aid. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

Clarence Elliott (Schooner), Bella Coola Band Age 16. Passed to Grade VIII at Alberni Indian Residential School last term. Parents promise maintenance, but may need food relief later. Grant required $105.00 for tuition & textbooks.

J. Amos Tellic, Bella Coola Band age 17. Passed to Grade VII from St Michael's Indian Residential School in 1948. Discharged at age 16, was eager to continue, but there was no room in Bella Coola Day School last term. He made arrangements to take correspondence course this year, they found there was room for one more in school bus and begged to be allowed to attend Provincial School. Maintains himself but had poor returns from fishing partly because of assuming debt to cannery of aged grandfather. This boy will probably need welfare aid, but his eagerness for education decided me to allow him the chance. Grant required $105.00 tuition & textbooks.

Louise Edgar, Bella Coola Band age 15. Passed to Grade VII from St. Michael's Indian Residential School last term. Parents promise full maintenance. Grant required $105.00 for tuition & textbooks.

Annie Harris, Bella Coola Band age 16. Passed to Grade VII at Bella Coola Indian Day School last term. I had been notified that this girl would not continue. However her father called on me a few days after school opened, and asked permission for her to attend the Provincial School. Her teacher from last term also spoke on her behalf and I consented. When she had been attending two weeks some of the white parents learned that she lived in the same home as a tubercular sister. A good deal of alarm was spread, and rather than jeopardise the good feeling that exists between whites & Indians...
I asked Annie to cease attendance. Now everything is being done to move the sick sister to hospital. If this can be accomplished soon, and Annie can successfully pass a further medical check, she will be allowed to return. Parents will give maintenance. Grant of $105.00 will be needed for tuition & textbooks if she returns.

Regarding the Bella Coola Indian Day School, there are 35 students registered in the junior room in Grade I and II. The Senior room has a registration of 27 in Grades III, IV, V. This is a small and old building which is rented from the Indians, it would not reasonably accommodate more than about two additional pupils for which no seats are on hand, although on order for some time. The building is not suitable for a classroom and it is hoped it may be vacated either by new construction by Indian Affairs, or by arrangement for the Provincial Government to construct additional classroom space to care for all Indian children above grade I and II. If this can be done next year it will be necessary to ask for accommodation from the Provincial Government for a total of 65 children, not allowing for children from other villages of the agency who may wish to attend High School here. It is hoped there may be several of these from Bella Bella bringing the total over 80. It is proposed to ask the Provincial Government to construct two new classrooms to take care of the needs of Bella Coola Indian children for next year. Present population figures indicate that about 15 new admissions will be sought for Indian Children to Bella Coola Provincial School each year over the next few years, beyond 1950.

Application forms and medical reports are attached for all new admissions this year except Annie Nappie. If she is to continue a new application will go forward for her later. It is regretted that this report has been so long delayed. This office has been without clerical help since June and there is much work in arrears. The application forms were lost in the melee over the past three weeks and have just been found.

Dear Sir:

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant regarding the allowance for janitor services at the Bella Coola Indian Day School.

As you are aware our funds at the present time are extremely limited and in addition it is felt that some of the best training that can be given at an Indian school is to teach the pupils the desirability of providing for themselves without cost to the Department. Consequently it is felt that the teachers can arrange to have the senior boys and girls assist in sweeping and cleaning the building and thus relieve the present janitor of the extra work that might be required in view of opening a second class room. You should confer with the teachers immediately and arrange for carrying out the Department's suggestion.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Agent,

Bella Coola, B.C.,
December 8, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Miss Isobel Leith, Principal of the Kitimat Indian Day School, has sent me a complaint of the inadequacy of the $4.00 allowed for janitor services and has apparently discussed this situation with the Kitimat Council. She writes as follows:

"The Council also discussed the question of fireman for the school and feel that the person doing it should get $10.00 per month. Wilfred Grant is doing it at present and is doing a satisfactory job. At present he expects to be here for the winter but if he is only allowed $4.00 at the school he will not promise to stay. From what I have been able to learn there will not be many of the men remaining in the village for long at a time during the winter so that it has been very difficult to get someone to do this job. As I told you when you were here we have to have someone to do this job as I haven't the physical strength to do it. As I said before, the Council feels that for the work involved the fireman should get $10.00 and they would like to take the matter up with the department."

Miss Leith has been informed of the Department's ruling in a similar request for Bella Bella—see file 14-162 letter dated December 25, 1939, and that she must not incur any expenses for janitor services exceeding $4.00 per month without the Department's permission.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

WO:MC

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6490, file 42162-6, part 2)
Ottawa,
December 22, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant with reference to the allowance for caretaking at the Kitimat Day School. From January 1, 1942, the Department will allow $5.00 a month for the janitor work at this school. From the same date a similar amount will be allowed for the janitor work at the Bella Bella Indian Day School, if you consider such action necessary. This is the other two-roomed school in your Agency.

Although it has been decided to increase the allowance for janitor services as shown above, I still feel that it is most important to direct the attention of all teachers to the contents of official letter of December 26, 1939. For training purposes I believe that it is a good plan to have the senior boys and girls assist in sweeping and cleaning the building.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Bella Coola Day School Janitor Services

Miss Wright has been in regarding the above subject. The teachers have been doing the janitor work, lighting fires, etc., for the $4.00 per month per room that has been provided. It has not proved satisfactory to have the children do this work so during the past rather severe winter this task has been an additional burden on the two teachers, neither of whom were in the best physical condition. Miss Wright now feels that she cannot undertake to light fires and do the heavy cleaning any longer, and hopes that the Department will make some provision for janitor service.

I have been considering lately the rehabilitation of an ex T.B. patient, a man of very small and slight stature and quite unfit for any of the heavy work in which most of the Indians engage, but fortunately with a very dependable character. I have a plan which may give this man partial independence of which I will write you further when the details have been worked out.

It has occurred to me that this man or some similarly placed individual would probably undertake to light the fires in the two school houses and do some of the heavier cleaning for about fifty cents per day for each school or in round figures $25.00 per month for the two buildings. The dusting might be done by one of the pupils on a voluntary basis, although this will probably still fall back on the teachers.

I would recommend therefore that the present allowance of $8.00 be increased to $25.00 per month for janitor service at these two schools.

Bella Coola, B.C.,
October 3rd, 1947

Major D. M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Janitor Services - Bella Coola Day School

May I refer again to your 2-11-8 of April 24th in which authority was given to pay $15.00 per month for janitor services for the two buildings of the above named school.

Matthew Moody, who was nominated to do this work, went to Nama Cannery during the holidays where he is now working as a watchman but will probably be here again this month. When I discussed the school janitor work with him last I thought I detected some reluctance, which it seemed to me had cooled his earlier enthusiasm for the over all scheme for his rehabilitation including the shop repair business. This and the fact that everyone approached avoided taking this work even when willing caused me to look more carefully into what was involved and I have come to the conclusion that no one will do the work without higher remuneration.

In the meantime one of the older people in the village, Peter Nelson has been lighting the fires only in the senior room each morning for twenty-five cents per day. His services have proved most satisfactory but he is unwilling to carry on any longer without higher remuneration. Miss Wright is continuing to attend to the cleaning but has asked me to get someone for the work as soon as possible. Mrs. Smoakgrass at the senior school house continues to do both fires and cleaning, but should be relieved of this work before the severe weather.

Following are details of the work expected of the janitor.

Junior School House

Building 40' x 25' consisting of one large classroom (34 desks), 2 large cloakrooms, stairs to basement, front porch with two sets of steps, full concrete basement, two toilets, two wash basins, furnace in centre of basement, wood storage at one end and toilets and wash-basins at the other end. The soil in the playground is fine gravel sand mixed with loam and tracks in freely owing to frequent wet weather.

Daily Work Required

School room, cloak rooms, porch, steps, stairs to basement, thoroughly swept; wash basins and toilets cleaned; blackboards washed. A conservative estimate of time required for this work would be one and one quarter hours daily. To light fires, cut kindling, empty ashes and sweep basement, each day roughly one half hour. Averaging 21 school days per month at 1½ hours each 36½ hours.

Monthly Work Required

Scrub classroom and cloakroom floors, scrub outside steps, porch and stairs to basement, time about 12 hours per mo.
Window cleaning 105 panes inside and out 4 "
Thoroughly cleaning basement 1½ "
Monthly allowance for incidentals as snow shovelling in winter, cutting brush on playground, and attending grounds in summer. 4 "
Cleaning woodwork, sweeping down cobwebs, etc. 1 "
Total monthly work 22½ "
Total of daily work for month as above 36½ "
Total for Junior room per month 59 hours
Senior Room

This classroom is much smaller. It is hoped a cloakroom entry will be added this year, however wood must be carried from a shed at the rear of the building.

Daily Work

Sweeping, washing blackboards, cleaning outside toilets, carrying wood and lighting fires one hour per day.

Monthly Work

To include cleaning windows, dusting down walls, scrub cloakroom and steps with allowance for snow shovelling, cutting brush, etc.

Total - 5 hours. Total daily work 1 hour @ 21 days per month = 21 hours plus 5 hours monthly work = 26 hours total.

Adding junior and senior rooms total 85 hours.

Travelling time

The schools are at opposite ends of the village, several trips per day will be made between buildings at ½ hour per day = 5 hrs. per mo.

Total of work required each month = 90 hours

Rate of pay at $15.00 per month = 18.66 cents per hour

I believe it will be difficult to have this work satisfactorily done at a rate which would work out at less than 40 cents per hour.

May consideration be given to increasing the monthly remuneration for janitor work at these two school buildings to $36.00 per month?

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Janitor Service -
Bella Coola Indian Day School

Replying to your 2-11-2 of October 14th, I wish to thank you for the consideration that has been given this matter and for the raising of the janitor allowance to the maximum amount.

During the past month, Alex King, Indian merchant and son of Chief Sam King has been lighting the fires in the junior room gratis. I am endeavoring to find someone to give each of the buildings a special cleaning from the money saved in this way. Each of the teachers will be paid the customary $4.00 for attending to daily cleaning.

Referring to the second paragraph of your letter, I find in each of the native communities a few people who, like Alex King here, have a sense of community welfare and are glad to donate time and money to anything that is of benefit to their village. However these few are likely to become discouraged if they find they are doing all the giving while others who do not think as they do benefit from their efforts without attempting to help. Again these matters can only be adjusted by local government and much time and attention is required before local Indian councils in this agency will be able to govern their own villages.

I have not yet arrived at a conclusion regarding a satisfactory way of making a compulsory tax levy which is the foundation of proper village government. I am now recommending to the Councils that a system of voluntary contribution be started where it is advertised publicly which property owners are paid up and which delinquent. This is not entirely satisfactory but is the best that can be done without consultation. Even this plan will pose difficulties to most of the Councils in this agency and may not prove satisfactory.

I have discussed the janitor service with the two school teachers and in order to do as much as we can for the larger school building where they are only Grade I and II children, Mrs. Smoggrass, teacher of the senior room, has offered to carry on with fire lighting and daily cleaning with the aid of older children in her room. I propose that you pay her payment of $4.00 per month for her work, from the $20.00 you are prepared to recommend, this will leave $16.00 to be devoted mostly to the larger building with a monthly special cleaning at the smaller school. The small children in the larger building will continue to do the dusting and other services will be scaled down to fit the money available. This plan will go into operation when you have given final authority and when Matthew Woody returns to the village, as he still seems the only hope for a steady janitor. He is expected to return within the next few weeks. Meantime Alex King has kindly offered to attend to fire lighting. Daily cleaning will be attended to by the teachers.

Although the care of school grounds, etc. will have to be waived and window cleaning, scrubbing, basement cleaning, etc. done less frequently, it is hoped that the $16.00 will do a passable job with the cooperation as indicated of the teachers and pupils.
However when the moneys available for these purposes are increased I would recommend a reconsideration of this item.

May I therefore have your authority to apply $20.00 per month to janitor services at the Bella Coola Day School as soon as possible.

Bella Coola, B.C.,
February 10th, 1949.

Dept. Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Canada.

Replying to you 42162-6 (E.I) of January 31st, the $20.00 per month assigned to janitor services at the Bella Coola schools are used as follows.

To the teacher Senior school, to cover sweeping, dusting and fire lighting and scrubbing - $4.00. (The Senior school operates in an old building which the Indians have loaned to the Department. There is no plumbing problem.)

To the teacher of the Junior school - $16.00. This fund is disbursed by the teacher as follows.

To an Indian woman for doing a general clean each day $6.00

To an Indian youth for lighting fires in the furnace each morning and preparing fuel for the day $6.00

Used by the teacher to provide scrubbing, window cleaning, etc. $4.00

$16.00

Fires in the furnace at the Junior school are maintained by the teacher during the day. In cold weather the fire lighter has been giving the extra service of stoking a fire during the evening to maintain enough heat to protect the plumbing overnight.

During the Christmas holidays the fire lighter visited the school about once every two hours every day to maintain satisfactory heat in the building. This was a considerable economic loss to him since he had to travel some distance from the forest where he was engaged in wood cutting. It has been most difficult to find reliable fire lighters and it should be noted that the teacher lives at some distance from the school. The $10.00 paid to the fire lighter for the extra service during the holidays only partially paid him for the time devoted to the work.

W. F. Padden, Indian Supt.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated November 24, 1930, in regard to janitor's fees for the Seabird Island Indian Day School.

In regard to this I beg to say that I interviewed the teacher, Miss Christine MacLennan, and she informed me that she had had to clean the school from floor to ceiling, and I saw her at it. The school is used as a council house, or rather the school is in the council house, and the Indians use it very frequently, in the evenings weekdays and on Sundays and Saturdays, but do not clean it up. They leave it very dirty, which naturally the teacher objects to. I have endeavored to get the Indians to keep the place clean, but have been unsuccessful.

I would recommend that $10.00 a month be paid the teacher as janitor's fees, and vouchers are enclosed for the months of September, October, November and December, amounting to $40.00.

Your obedient servant,

(A. Strang)
Acting Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 28, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a voucher in favour of Miss L. Blachford, teacher of the Boothroyd Indian Day School, in payment of janitor services for the months of February and March at the rate of $10 per month.

In this connection I have to say that this appears to be the first request for payment of janitor services at this school and, while the Department will allow Miss Blachford remuneration for this work, I have to say that the rate usually allowed is $7.50 per month for the ten teaching months in the year. For this amount, teachers either perform the janitor's duties themselves or have Indians do certain of the cleansing, etc., for which the teachers remunerate them from the salary allowed. As funds are very limited, we can only allow Miss Blachford payment at the rate of $7.50 per teaching month during the next fiscal year. This is to include all cleaning, lighting fires, etc., required at the school. A cheque in payment for the two above named months at the rate mentioned will be sent in due course. In future, you may forward these vouchers at the end of each quarter for payment at the rate mentioned.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Sir:

I am in receipt of the vouchers which you issued in favour of the teachers of the Seton Lake and Boothroyd Indian Day Schools for janitor services for the quarter ended June 30th, last.

The Salary Deduction Act passed at the last Session of Parliament provided that, when paying salaries, the total compensation must be considered. Mr. Grist, teacher of the Seton Lake Indian Day School, is paid salary at the rate of $950 a year and $75 a year for janitor services, making his total compensation $1025.00. When the total compensation is more than $1,000 but does not exceed $1,111, the Act mentioned above requires that the total remuneration that can be allowed is $1,000 a year. On the basis of ten teaching months in the school year, Mr. Grist was entitled to $300 for the months of April, May and June. For Treasury Branch
D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver.

Re: Fuel for Homalco Indian Day School.

I would advise that in the past, wood has been purchased for heating the above school classroom and coal has been purchased for the kitchen range in the adjoining teacher's residential quarters.

Wood is very difficult to obtain at Church House. The Indians ask $9.50 a cord, and delivery is usually very dilatory and now quite problematical.

Coal has been shipped from Vancouver but difficulties are encountered in getting Indians to haul it from wharf to school, even although they are paid for their work. Last winter two sacks of coal were stolen in transit from the wharf but the thief was not located.

The coal last supplied was of poor quality as I found when visiting Church House. Furthermore, the coal sacks have to be returned by the teacher to Vancouver in order that a refund be obtained for the Department.

To obviate these difficulties I would recommend purchase of oil burners for use in both the heater and the kitchen range, especially as a supply of fuel oil is guaranteed by the Yuclataw Traders store on Stuart Island who offer a pot burner type oil heater for $55.00.

Local quotations were requested for a range oil burner and the only wickless type offered is $44.62

/OVER.
complete with tank stand assembly and all fittings. Wick burners are much less satisfactory and are quoted at $44.50.

If approval is given I will submit a requisition with details of tenders received.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

AA.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Taylor's letter of June 25th in connection with difficulties encountered in providing fuel for the Homalco Indian Day School wherein he suggests that consideration be given to the supply of an oil heater and gives assurance that supplies of oil will be available.

In view of the uncertainty in the matter of the supply of coal and wood I concur in his recommendation for the supply of an oil heater and a range oil burner at a cost of approximately $100.00. If the Department concurs in this recommendation I will ask Mr. Taylor to secure quotations and also to give an estimate of the cost of fuel oil for both the heater and the range for a school term.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
